"Right. Now let's get to it," the lieutenant nods.
"I've got one in the Kineema's toolbox. We should go back for it before we continue. No sense in tripping around in the darkness."

"This would be a lot easier with a flashlight..."

"I was to meet a detective from Precinct 41 at the Whirling-in-Rags who arrived here three days ago. I am told that that is how long you have been here. Besides, you match his description." He looks you over.

"...where it has been hanging for seven days straight. We should go there as soon as we're done talking to the owner."

"Oh..." There's a moment's pause, then he continues, carefully: "If you didn't have your badge then that would be very *bad*. You would need to report it on my shortwave. But since you *do* have it, we can go straight to the task at hand."
A bespectacled man in an orange bomber jacket is tapping his foot on the floor. Looks like he's waiting for someone -- you.
"Hello, I'm Kim Kitsuragi." His grip is firm. "Lieutenant, Precinct 57. You must be from the 41st..."
"Okay. We'll have time for that after we take a look at the coroner's case."

"We all feel that way sometimes. There is no such thing as a *police officer*, I'm afraid. What remains is that there is a dead body in the tree -- someone has to figure out who put it there. If we don't, no one else will."
"Yes."
"Have you removed the dead body from the tree?"
You realize he is waiting for your name.
"Yes. But I am not them. I'm from Criminal Investigation."
"Yes. But I am not them. I'm from Criminal Investigation."
"After it's been up in a tree for that long, any kind of ripping is inadvisable."
"Yes, well..." He doesn't even process what you just said, just moves on.
"So, the body is still in the tree..."
"Mm-hmm."
"Internal affairs. And I'm not them. I'm from Criminal Investigation."
"You may have murdered the man I was supposed to meet and are now impersonating him. You may be his twin, stepping in for his even more incapacitated brother out of loyalty and love."
"No, I don't think so." He studies you briefly. "We should ask him for a run-down of the area now that I'm here as well. I understand the scene is out back, right?"
"It also wouldn't hurt to assure him the police are finally here. In full force, I mean. Have you mapped out the initial interviews?"
"I can see you drank last night, and the night before," he says after a moment of silence. "And that you are still drunk now. But I have seen officers go through worse. Much worse."
"Sure. But did you take it down from the tree?"

"They're not *just* white rectangles. They bear a halogen watermark with the letters RCM and a pattern resembling the street grid of Revachol West. I could step into the headlights of my Kineema and show you, but right now I just need you to do your job."
"You seem a little unsure, officer. Have you spent too much time undercover lately?" He cracks an uneasy smile to let you know it's a joke.

"At the 57th, we like to prepare an initial list of persons of interest and then just... skim the surface." He gestures with his fingers. "Prepare the field, get to know the players. You don't do that? Maybe it's not an inter-district practice..."
"If you need something for your headache, there is a general store nearby. But, as I said, the dead body should be our number one concern."
"They're not *just* white rectangles. They bear a halogen watermark with the letters RCM and a pattern resembling the street grid of Revachol West."

After catching your attention, he narrows his eyes and extends his hand in greeting.

"Does that mean the body is no longer in the tree?"
"Completely? Does that mean you took the body down from the tree?"
"Sure. Though I would also suggest that you locate your blazer with your official insignia." He points to the white rectangle on his sleeve.

"Losing your identification card is a *serious* matter. My vehicle has a shortwave -- you can use it to report your badge missing. I advise you to try to locate it as quickly as possible. But getting the body down should still take precedence."

"Oh..." There's a moment's pause, then he continues, obviously relieved: "If you didn't have your badge then that would be very *bad*. You would need to report it on my shortwave. But since you *do* have it, we can go straight to the task at hand."

"Losing your identification card is a *serious* matter. My vehicle has a shortwave -- you can use it to report your badge missing. I would advise you to locate it as quickly as possible. But getting the body down should still take precedence."
"I would ask you to step into the headlights of my motor carriage, but, again, it's none of my concern. I just need you to do your job."
"But for now I am going to set those possibilities aside. I'm not from the Inspectorate General."

"If you don't mind, we should talk to him again. Ask him for a run-down of the area -- now that I'm here as well. I understand the scene is out back, right?"
"You mean you don't have a badge?"
"Talk to the manager. Then we go out back and take the body down."
"Precinct 41 said they were sending their most seasoned detective. And you certainly look... seasoned."
"Right... Now, I know it took us a while to arrive at the scene. It also took you a while to call us and report the dead body -- it *was* you who placed the call, yes?"
"That's good. But there is a timetable for this investigation, dictated to us by the stages of decomposition. And it says we need to move on."
"I am Kim Kitsuragi from Precinct 57. This is an inter-district investigation, so joining me from Precinct 41..." He looks to you, realizing he still doesn't know your name.
"You said you just got here -- from where? Are you a local?"

"No, don't, there's no need..." A pattern of creases appears on his forehead. "You really need to take this up with your station, I have a shortwave radio in my car. Call them, ask for assistance. We have to get this investigation started now."
"Forty one," the lieutenant steps in.

"Officer..." A pattern of creases appears on his forehead. "You really need to take this up with your station, I have a shortwave radio in my car. Call them, ask for assistance. We have to get this investigation started now."
"Let's go."
He turns to you, calmly. "We do not need to assert ourselves here. We only need instructions from him. This is the proprietor, remember?"
The lieutenant stands motionless, his expression unreadable.
"Did the Débardeurs themselves tell her this, or is it a rumour?"
"I didn't imply that." He turns to you. "Detective?"
"Yes, Detective Costeau." He says the name with a purposefully straight face. "I have everything. You?"
"Mhm." He checks his little notebook. "I have everything. You?"
"I know it took us a while to arrive at the scene. But it also took you a while to call us. It was you who placed the call, correct?"
"Sir, I understand your concern, but we're here to do a job, and for us to do it, I need you to stay calm."
"Sir, leash in your tongue." The lieutenant's voice is controlled, yet threatening. Like it's coming from a different person.
"Okay..." The lieutenant lets out a heavy sigh. "Let's go. Goodbye, sir."
The lieutenant nods at you affirmatively, then glances at the exit. "The body was behind the building, right -- how do we get there?"

"Officer," he turns to you. "You need to contact your station. Ask your people for assistance with the money you owe this place. There is a shortwave radio in my car, when you get the time, use it. We need to get this investigation started now."
There's a shuffle of nylon as Lieutenant Kitsuragi looks for something in the pockets of his orange bomber.
The lieutenant turns the page in the little notebook he's been scribbling in.
The lieutenant watches you fiddle with your horrific tie, sweat stains forming under your armpits. He puts his hand on your shoulder.
"No, there's no need..." The lieutenant is silent for a moment. "Let's go. Goodbye, sir."
"That's enough." You can't tell who the remark is aimed at, you or Garte.
"That's enough now, sir. Good day."
"If you don't have the money, it's okay. None of us are in this for the wages."
"I have everything. You?" He looks in his little notebook.
The lieutenant looks at you tugging on your garish tie. He puts his hand on your shoulder:
There's a shuffle of nylon as Lieutenant Kitsuragi looks for something in the pockets of his orange bomber.

"I'm sorry I couldn't help more." Creases line his forehead, above the spectacles. "You should take this up with your station, I have a shortwave radio in my car, okay? We have to get this investigation started now."
"Mr... Garte, right?" The lieutenant glances into his little notebook. "You run this place?"
"Officer, maybe you're better off working this from home for now? You live in Jamrock, right? It's not that far away."
"Khm..." The lieutenant coughs in your direction. "Not now."
"You mean the strike?"
"But you still know your way around, yes? In case we need directions."
"It is crude of you. A man has been killed. File a request for compensation with Station 41. We need to work now."
"And how do we get there?"
"Do you have her number?"
"Thank you," the lieutenant says. He opens his little notebook at the cover. The number is safely tucked away in a small pocket.
"Officer... I was thinking more along the lines of your name."
"It's your turn." He takes a respectful little step back.
"Some do take recompense." The lieutenant is dead serious. "But only to survive."
"But, you see, he didn't."
"There's a greenhouse here -- and a gardener with a wheelbarrow on the corner of the Whirling-in-Rags. If she works here she might have something for the smell."
"No. This is a two-man assignment, because it needs two officers to complete. I need your help." He withdraws his hand and looks you in the eye:
"Officer, you just need to be stronger. Learn to keep it in long enough for us to work. There's nothing else *to* do."
"By *ka-ching* do you mean..." He tilts his head. "'Let's not log them as evidence, let's steal them'?"
"Did we? I don't *feel* lucky."
"There's always a chance. We should check for ligament marks on his neck to see if they're in tune with the belt. We'll have to get him *down* first..."
"No, you're right. The harbour uses six-rotors to shuffle containers around. They used whatever was on hand here. Without paying attention to not incriminating themselves."
"There are no supra-natural reasons," the lieutenant says, marking something in his notebook.
"And what kind of lesson is that?" Just like that the gun has left your hand. The lieutenant holsters it.
The gun has left your hand, still numb from the recoil. The lieutenant holsters it under his arm.
"There's the Frittte nearby -- maybe they have some in their apothecary? If they don't..." He points to the greenhouse.
"A good point. He could have been intoxicated. Or something we cannot yet imagine... I shouldn't have assumed so much just from the clothes."
"They do after seven days, yes. We're deep in decomposition here."
"Monday -- make sure you bring a handkerchief."
"They're armour, not boots." With his notebook under his arm the lieutenant crouches to inspect the soles: "Technically speaking these are *sabatons*."

"There's no way you're getting them off. All the organic matter in his body has been flowing down into the boots. They're *fused* to his feet now -- why do you think the locals haven't scavenged them yet?"
"It *does* make sense, doesn't it? Besides..." The lieutenant taps on the boot.
"As I said it's been below freezing since last Sunday. Today is the first chance to thaw. Things would be... *worse* if it had thawed earlier."
"An instant colour camera." He produces two metal-capped ampoules and clicks them into place on the side of the apparatus. A thin slot shines there...
"Hmh... The steel-reinforced belt presents a *unique* challenge. I brought chain-cutters, but I don't see a good angle of approach to the belt."
"I don't doubt your physical prowess, officer, but this is a gruelling surgical procedure. I saw twenty steel strands in there -- and we do not have a secure platform for the cutting."
"I think you have your sports mixed up there, officer, squaring my shoulders has nothing to do with this."
"Go ahead, I'm not stopping you. Just don't lose it." The piece shines in his outstretched hand.
The lieutenant follows suit. He finishes loading the gun in silence, then hands it to you.
"*Extremely* unfortunate. You need to contact your station about it as soon as possible." The piece shines in his outstretched hand. "Try not to lose this one, please."
"We still need to get him down *somehow*." His tone is growing tired now -- the stench makes him turn away from the corpse.
"Everything here seems to corroborate that assumption. But we should still get him *down* before assigning a probable cause of death."
"To ask the *suspects* for help with the victim's body? To be indebted to Evrart Claire? Very much, yes -- which is why I would have preferred us to handle this ourselves."
"Okay..." He looks at the cargo belt. "They *do* have the tools and the men. And since it looks like they *put* him there..."
"Yes." He agrees. "The debrief we got from the Wild Pines representative appears to be solid too. A lynching is what this looks like. Our internal RCM brief said the same..." He looks at you.
"No, I think he had something precious underneath his clothes. They had to remove the *jeans* we found in the trash to get to it. This kind of armour is often worn *under* fabric."
"There's Frittte nearby, east of the hostel. They usually have a small apothecary. If they don't..." He points to the greenhouse.
"I think I've lost my sense of smell." There's a pause.
"Yes, that's what I said. You'll compromise the coroner's case if you do. So please *don't*."
"Even the mongrels can see you're about to pull his head off."
"This is not the *enemy*, this is the deceased. The victim. In a murder investigation."
"No. You should *not* get a drink. You should perform an initial inspection of the victim's corpse -- we're on the rope part."
"Then you should ask me the first moment we get."
"Agreed." He points to the belt. "Especially on the neck. The belt acted like a tourniquet keeping the blood in his head. The hypostasis supports a hanging."
"Climb up there and... saw the branch?"
"I think you're underestimating the gravity of this situation, officer. We need to take a breather from this scene." He points at you. "Now."
"At least you understand the gravity of the situation, detective. We need to take a breather from this scene." He points at you. "Now."
"The *bad* way -- the way I didn't want us to." He sighs. "By asking the harbour for help. They have the tools and the men. If they put him up there -- they can take him down too."
"No?" The lieutenant's expression is stern and impenetrable. He points at you: "You *will* get your shit together."
"I have no idea what that means."
"This material is a kinetic re-distributor. It spreads kinetic energy horizontally. From plate to plate. When the plates connect there's a click." He points to the toe. "See these lines?"
"Stop obsessing about your sexuality officer, you're about to seriously compromise the coroner's case."
"I don't think we should *do* anything just for the hell of it. Besides..." The lieutenant taps on the boot.
"We should have a look at that belt before we even *consider* taking him down. It looks worrisome." (He points to the belt around his neck.)
"I have only a cursive knowledge of the science of cybernetics -- I would not know if it were. But it's not *quite* complex enough, is it?"
"I agree." A sudden ring fills the air as the lieutenant pulls down the zipper of his orange jacket.
"Yes..." He slides the camera closed and tucks it away on his belt. "It is pretty *cool*, isn't it?"
"I don't trust that ladder. The assailants didn't use it. It's rotten and less sturdy than it looks. And I don't see another good way up there."
He then steps back and assumes the Falostesse position, taking aim. The corner of his eye twitches -- his finger is on the trigger...
"Don't provoke her." The lieutenant takes his sidearm from you, then holsters it.
"I can't say I'm *fully* satisfied with that part. We should search for prints maybe..." He points to the spring mud around you.
"Four and final: transport of the coroner's case to the district morgue. I'll do that." The lieutenant stops. "God, he stinks."
"Yes..." He nods slowly. "And those were the interviewees. Let's go."
"Sure you do. You just threw up *a lot*."
"As a wage, it's regrettably small. But for a piece of hardware -- yes, that's a lot."
"No." He shakes his head. "Your first instinct was correct. This equipment is way beyond what a security guard can afford."
"Stop!" The lieutenant's voice is sharp. He looks at you, with the boot under your arm.
"I do. Most of them are postmortem. Maybe even all of them. The delinquents have made our jobs harder with their little sport."
"Airlifting? I thought it was used on lorries -- for strapping cargo to them."
"That ladder can't carry a grown man. I didn't see any splintering either, did you? I think they lassoed the branch, then pulled on the belt to close the buckle..." He makes a pulling motion.

"A map of the stars?" He turns around to breathe before inspecting it closer. "I do see some similarity to astronomical charts, Great Century Messinian maybe... But this seems more particular. Customized somehow."
"In case we need it," the lieutenant says and shakes the paper, letting it dry in the cold wind. On it -- a colour-perfect copy of the dead man's tattooed chest.
"Hmm..." The lieutenant marks something in his notebook.
"I wasn't actually implying I would. I meant it's a bad idea."
"What else can we do?"
"God damn it."
"I agree. Police work is overrated. It is trying and stressful. However, it is still our job to get the dead body down from the tree." He takes his sidearm from you and holsters it.
"The cadaver is already compromised bad enough. We don't have to make it *worse*."
"I'm satisfied with that part. The trash container, the prints -- we've been thorough enough."
"Two: Initial examination of the victim. We were pretty good in our efforts -- and the autopsy will provide another chance."
"Three: Field autopsy. This will *not* be pleasant. Or easy. And it *will* have to be performed on the scene."
"An honour -- and a burden. Attached to your rank. Mine is *lieutenant-detective* -- unfortunately. I can't tell you how tired I am of this corpse..."

"In the meantime, we should locate the representative of the logistics company. My preliminary information suggests the Wild Pines have sent a strike negotiator to wrangle back control from the Union."
"If you can handle the headache," he nods. "Some officers use it to deal with cadaverine odour."
"It's anything but. This material is a kinetic re-distributor. It spreads kinetic energy horizontally, from plate to plate. Dissipating it entirely." He points to the boots. "See?"
"I'm sorry. I didn't even want to take them off, I just thought I should try."
The lieutenant's face is made of stone.
"We all are." He covers his nose. "This belt worries me."
"I have only two ampoules, so nobody move -- I don't want to waste one." He points the camera at the corpse, peering into it. The lens needs adjusting. Then:
"Absolutely."
"Honestly, I prefer a *non-acrobatic* solution to this." He looks around -- then at you.
"What I'm proposing is -- we save acrobatic tricks as a last resort. After we've tried *everything* else."
"We try something else."
"No."
"It looks like *I* feel like taking a break from the stench. I'm sorry to interrupt the jubilations here -- just a little breather before we do the autopsy."
"The stench is getting bad. I'm sorry to interrupt the jubilations here -- I need a little breather before we do the autopsy."
"Two: Initial examination of the victim. We were not exhaustive in our efforts, should have looked at the tattoos maybe? But what's done is done."
"Good."
"The risk of... acrobatic failure is one we cannot take. We must not become *comedy* for the locals."
"Fine, then." The piece shines in his outstretched hand.
The lieutenant pays no heed: "We should go and do something else. Give it half an hour. Then come back, when you've gotten your act together."
He breathes out heavily.

"I've seen *captains* puke their guts out. It never gets easier, you never get used to the smell. Every Monday is cadaver day -- throw up, investigate, throw up, initial autopsy, throw up, bag it..." He pats your back again.
"No, it's not officer."
"Not too much, yes."
He nods: "Piece by piece. He's been out here for seven days -- it would be odd if they didn't."
"Okay. Fine. You want to protect the *feet* of six dead men. That's commendable. But..." The lieutenant taps on the boot.
"Oh," he snorts. "You're trying to assess *lividity*."
"Maybe it looks faint to you?" He leans closer, covering his nose: "It *could* be more pronounced, actually. Dûment noté."
"A noose is one of those things that's easier to use one way around..." He points to the buckle tying the belt to the branch above.
"Oh, no." He shakes his head slowly. "We should be *very* afraid of newspapers. And the radio stations too. We should be wary of enticing them in *any* way."
Silence. With his elbows sharp, the lieutenant unzips his jacket...
The kid's voice is drowned in a shrill blast that echoes off the walls of the surrounding tenements. A cloud of smoke slowly parts in the air, as the lieutenant steps back and says to himself...
But then it does -- and with furious precision! The lieutenant is not one to leave an Ace's Low *hanging*.
"I can't say I'm satisfied with that part yet. We should search for prints maybe..." He stops to look at the spring mud. "And the trash container too..."
"We need to access the harbour and ask the leader of the Union to have it taken down. They have the tools -- and they have men."
He nods. "Right now everything seems to fit their confession."
"So am I." A sudden ringing fills the air as the lieutenant pulls down the zipper of his orange jacket.
"I've seen strong men turn themselves inside out for hours. You're facing tough odds here. Alcohol withdrawal makes it considerably harder."
The lieutenant nods, wiping his finger on his sleeve.
"For a full set of armour I wouldn't blame you. But these boots are hardly worth a disciplinary hearing. There are better ways to pay a hostel bill. Besides..." He taps the boot.
"We have a make and a number -- that's something. We can use the radio in my Kineema when we're done. Either station can chase it for us."
"That's for us to find out. My initial report on the area suggests he was a security guard for the harbour company -- but that's just hearsay."
"I agree. This equipment is *way* beyond what a guard can afford."
"Processing will take care of them. With the situation in the morgue, it will yield nothing. But we must pick our fights." He looks toward the boots. "Should we continue?"
"Totally dead."
"I have thought of that, yes. But the tyre tracks would compromise the scene. Any prints would become illegible. That's *if* we get it through the hole in the fence..."
"No, I do not see the future. I made those up using two decades in the Revacholian police force as a reference point."
"That is even *more* unfortunate than the badge. You need to contact your station about it as soon as possible." The piece shines in his outstretched hand. "Try not to lose this one, please."
"Are you sure we've finished the preliminary examination of the cadaver? We might miss some of these things once he's down." He stops to think, then checks his notes.
"Officer, let's keep our attention on the victim."
"Someone could have cleaned the yard. But that's a question for... the red-haired thing."
"Honestly -- a whole set of ceramics: the breastplate, the pauldrons... I wouldn't blame you. But these two? Not worth bringing Internal Affairs into your life over. Besides..." He taps the boot.
"That doesn't sound like a serial number. Where's the structure and logic of a line of manufactured products..." He pauses to think. "No matter. We should run it anyway."
"That doesn't mean anything, detective. Besides..." The lieutenant taps on the boot.
"Just something I scraped together from my station. An area report on Martinaise. I'm sure you did the same..."
"I see it." He adjusts his glasses. "His neck too, the lividity goes right up his chin. We have good, well-pronounced discolouration here..."
"Okay." He blinks. "You should ask me for one the first moment we get."
"I think they lassoed the branch, then pulled on the belt -- buckle closes." He makes a pulling motion. "It's what I would do. Seems easier than climbing up there."
He takes a thin piece of milled aluminium from his coat pocket and pulls it open. Sounds like a sword being unsheathed. A small lens appears -- some sort of camera.
"Who is he? He is male, forty to fifty. With an athletic build."
"Hmmm..." The lieutenant falls deep in thought.
"*Cretin Cop*... -- they like that word -- ...*Saws The Branch He's Sitting On (Literally)*. *Local Children Report Corpse Mutilation*."
"Yes. We should use acrobatics as the very last option. After we've tried *everything* normal."
The lieutenant gently picks his gun from your hand and holsters it.
"That is not important right now."
"Ace's high!" The lieutenant raises his right hand, waiting for you to slap it.
"We will perform a field autopsy and determine the cause of death -- but before... excuse me." He needs to turn away from the corpse.
"I am at a loss as well. I could *swear* your shit was together, detective."
"The leader of the Union. A dangerous and corrupt man. One you don't want to be *indebted* to."
"Then the world will turn away from you, and leave you behind."
"*They* usually hang them completely naked for that. La Puta Madre, the Mazda, the Besmerties, and the like. This one still has his underpants."
"You'd have to boil them in acid. Besides..." The lieutenant taps on the boot.
"Yes, there's always a chance we're wrong. We should check for ligament marks on his neck to see if they're in tune with the belt. We'll have to get him *down* first..."

"Uhm..." He considers it: "No. More like in a *harbour*. Like the one just east of here. I get the sense they used whatever was on hand, without paying much attention to not incriminating themselves."
"It's not merely polyester -- it's steel reinforced." He rises to inspect the noose. "See these lines? This is where the wires run. I see rabbets for more than twenty strands."
"How about I take *you* piggyback?" After a moment’s silence, he raises an eyebrow.
The lieutenant does not dignify that with an answer. He snaps the button on his holster and says...
There is silence.

"Okay," he mumbles for a second, then lowers his hand. "Maybe it's not customary in the 41st to perform an Ace's High. In the 57th we've carried over the custom from the Revolution. Maybe it's bad luck... anyway."
"I see what you mean, but even so..." The lieutenant taps on the boot.
"He worked for Krenel -- like Joyce told us. This is military equipment, provided by a wealthy security contractor. With state ties. *Way* above what we have."
"Mhm. It means 'disciplinary hearing'." The lieutenant nods, wiping his finger on his sleeve.
"Please stop trying to perform a *necromantic ritual*. We have other things to do."
"Hooray for us."
"From the gates -- by negotiating or fighting. I'm *unenthusiastic* about fighting..." He looks around. "Or we can try to find some secret third path -- it's unlikely, though."
"I was really hoping we wouldn't -- the Union appear to be *suspects* in this case. It seems like a dangerous route to go down."
"Yes." He agrees. "The debrief we got from the Wild Pines representative appears to be solid too. A lynching is what this looks like."
"It's okay, happens to everyone." The lieutenant hands you his white handkerchief: "Keep it."
"Get a hold of yourself." You feel the lieutenant pat your back, rhythmically.
